title: 106_s2310
content: The "Firearms Dealer Penalty Flexibility Act of 2000" allows for the suspension of a firearms dealer's license and imposes civil penalties. Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, allows the Secretary to suspend or revoke a license or impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations related to armor-piercing ammunition. The Secretary has the authority to suspend, revoke, or impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 on a dealer who willfully transfers armor-piercing ammunition. The Secretary can also compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for violations. Actions taken by the Secretary can only be reviewed as provided in subsection (f), which outlines the rights of applicants and licensees in case of denial, revocation, suspension, or civil penalty assessment. If the Secretary denies a license application, revokes or suspends a license, or assesses a civil penalty, written notice must be provided to the affected party stating the specific grounds. The affected party must receive notice before the effective date of revocation or suspension. An appeal process is available, including a hearing. The Secretary must provide written notice of license denial, revocation, or suspension before the effective date. An appeal process is available, including a hearing upon request. The Secretary must provide written notice of license denial, revocation, or suspension before the effective date, followed by an appeal process that includes a hearing upon request. If the Secretary decides not to reverse the decision, the aggrieved party can file a petition with the district court within 60 days of receiving notice. The aggrieved party can file a petition with the district court for a de novo judicial review of license denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment. The court may consider any evidence submitted by the parties in the proceeding. The district court can review license denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment with de novo judicial review. The court may consider evidence submitted by the parties, regardless of whether it was presented at the hearing. If the Secretary's actions are deemed unauthorized, the court can order necessary compliance. The district court can review license denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment with de novo judicial review. The court may consider evidence submitted by the parties, regardless of whether it was presented at the hearing. If the Secretary's actions are deemed unauthorized, the court can order necessary compliance. The Secretary shall stay the effective date of the revocation, suspension, or assessment pending an appeal under this paragraph. SEC. 3. Amends Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code, to terminate a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction.
